message: @KuraFire i might be interested in what someone is doing on convore, but not a friend of theirs, and not interested in following them on twitter, because theyr'e too verbose, or whatever
@KuraFire yeah, there are definitely gopher holes/snakepits

Honest question: what is there to gain from having a social graph inside Convore?  You can create private groups and simply invite only the people you want, not really anything that a Friend-connection matters in
it seems I have friends on convore who haven't connected to twitter or facebook
it would be great to be able to mark people as friends who don't connect to other networks
I think even if people I invited were added as friends
and then a "friend" button on peoples profiles
so when adding members to a group they don't come up as convore friends (at least I guess that is the reason)
Yeah, if you have any creative solutions to that, I'm all ears
the way the social graph works on convore is great for on-boarding, but is going to break down once people start using the site
yeah, I follow a lot of people on twitter I would never be comfortable inviting to a group
What's the point of friending someone here?
I dislike stimulating social graph-ness too much, everywhere. It _always_ leads to some people bickering completely unnecessarily about "why don't you follow me back?" or what-not

@djchall Problem with that is the complexity vs. worthwhile-ness tradeoff: what happens if I sign up with Twitter? Do all my Twitter friends become Convore friends? If not, what _does_ happen to them? I get to see their activity through Discover, after all.

@djchall Furthermore, what if Convore simply adds something like what Quora does to user profile pages, e.g. a log of their recent activity around the site? That way, you can always see that which you just described, without having to social graph the whole place up.
i've not used quora as much as i should, perhaps
@KuraFire yeah, that might be one solution
